TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, smectitic Abruptic Palecryolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Scave silt loam - native aspen, grasses and forbs.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
O1--2 to 0 inches; Matted decaying leaves and twigs.
A11--0 to 1O inches; dark brown (7.5YR 4/2) silt loam, very dark brown (7.5YR 2/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; many large and medium roots; few fine interstitial pores; 5 percent gravel; medium acid (pH 5.8); gradual wavy boundary. (10 to 16 inches thick)
A12--10 to 16 inches; dark brown (7.5YR 4/3) and brown (7.5YR 5/4) silt loam, very dark brown (7.5YR 2/2) moist weak medium subangular blocky structure that parts to moderate fine granular structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; many large, medium, and small roots; few fine interstitial pores; 15 percent gravel; medium acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary. (O to 10 inches thick)
A2--16 to 34 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) cobbly loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common medium and small roots, many medium and fine interstitial pores; 30 to 40 percent cobbles and gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.1); abrupt wavy boundary. (10 to 24 inches thick)
B21t--34 to 46 inches; reddish brown (2.5YR 5/4) very cobbly clay; red (2.5YR 4/6) moist; weak medium prismatic structure that parts to moderate medium subangular blocky structure; extremely hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few fine roots; many medium and fine tubular pores; moderately thick continuous clay films; 60 percent cobbles; medium acid (pH 5.6); few fine black concretions and stains; gradual wavy boundary. (12 to 20 inches thick)
B22t--46 to 56 inches; same as B21t horizon but with 80 to 90 percent cobbles and a few stones. (Not sampled.)

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Cache County, Utah; 1.5 miles south and 2 miles west of Anderson Range headquarters; about 1,000 feet north of the center of sec. 9, T.9N., R.3E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS: The mollic epipedon ranges from 10 to 16 inches thick. The combined thickness of the Al, A2 and B2t horizons is 60 to more than 75 inches. There is an abrupt texture change between the A2 horizon and the B2t horizon at depths of 24 to 45 inches. Clay content increases more than 20 percent within a vertical distance of less than 3 inches. Rock fragments are mainly cobble and stone size angular sandstone and rounded quartzite rock fragments ranging from about 5 to 20 percent in the Al horizons, 30 to 70 percent in the A2 horizon, and 35 to 70 percent in the upper part of the B2t horizon, 70 to 90 percent in the lower part of the B2t horizon. The mean annual soil temperature ranges from 38 to 45 degrees F., and the mean summer soil temperature at a depth of about 20 inches ranges from 52 to 58 degrees F. The soils are moist for 55 to 65 percent of the time and are dry in parts of the 4 to 12 inch depth for 60 to 75 days during the late summer or early autumn.
The Al horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 2 through 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3. It has weak to moderate, fine to medium granular structure or weak subangular blocky structure in the lower part. This horizon ranges from medium acid to neutral.
The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR, 7.5YR or 5YR, value of 5 through 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4. It ranges from cobbly loam or very cobbly loam to gravelly fine sandy loam. This horizon has weak to moderate, fine to coarse subangular blocky structure. It is strongly acid to slightly acid.
The B2t horizon has hue of 5YR or 2.5YR, value of 5 through 7 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 4 through 8. It is very cobbly or very gravelly clay or very cobbly heavy clay loam with more than 35 percent clay. This horizon has weak to strong, medium to coarse prismatic structure that parts to blocky structure. It ranges from medium acid to neutral. It has few to continuous, thin or moderately thick clay films on peds and in pores.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: These are the Cluff, Flygare, Lucky Star, Pritchett, Red Spur and Roundy series. Cluff soils lack mollic epipedons. Flygare and Red Spur soils have mollic epipedons more than 16 inches thick and have cobbly sandy clay loam argillic horizons with less than 35 percent clay. Lucky Star soils have albic horizons that tongue into very cobbly sandy clay loam argillic horizons. Pritchett soils have hue of 10YR or 7.5YR in the B2t horizon. Roundy soils have mollic epipedons more than 16 inches thick and have argillic horizons of cobbly clay containing less than 35 percent rock fragments.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: SETTING: Scave soils are on moderately steep to very steep mountain slopes at elevations of 6,200 to 9,200 feet. Slope gradients are 6 to 50 percent. Parent rocks are dominantly sandstone with some quartzite, limestone and shale. The climate is moist subhumid with warm dry summers and cold moist winters. The average annual precipitation ranges from 20 to 35 inches. The mean annual temperature ranges from 39 to 45F. The mean summer temperature is 54 to 58 degrees F. The frost free period is 80 to 100 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: PRINCIPAL ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the competing Lucky Star soils and the Ant Flat, Charcol, Despain, Hoskin and Schuster soils. Ant Flat, Despain and Hoskin soils lack A2 horizons. Also, Ant Flat soils are not gravelly or cobbly and have horizons of carbonate accumulation. Charcol soils have mollic epipedons more than 20 inches thick and have less than 35 percent clay in the argillic horizons. Despain soils have gravelly clay loam argillic horizons with less than 35 percent gravel and have horizons of carbonate accumulation. Hoskin soils have very gravelly loam argillic horizons. Schuster soils lack abruptic texture change and have less than 35 percent clay in the argillic horizons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Well drained; slow runoff; slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: These soils are used for watershed and rangeland for grazing of livestock and wildlife. The native vegetation is aspen with widely spaced Douglas-fir and subalpine fir, understory of snowberry, mountain bromegrass, blue wildrye, oniongrass, slender wheatgrass, peavine, horsemint, geranium and sweet-anise.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: High mountain areas of northern Utah. This series is inextensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED: Cache County Utah 1972.
REMARKs: The Scave soils were formerly classified as Brunizems intergrading to Gray Wooded soils.
OSED scanned by NSSQA.  Last revised by state 11/74.
